thread.title: Apple slapped with $5m class-action suit over iOS 9’s Wi-Fi
thread.title_full: Apple slapped with $5m class-action suit over iOS 9’s Wi-Fi - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Apple slapped with $5m class-action suit over iOS 9’s Wi-Fi
text:
Apple You can use the Wi-Fi Assist feature with all iOS devices that support iOS 9, including iPhone 5/5s and later models. A couple is suing Apple after they received an astronomical bill because of Wi-Fi Assist.
On Friday, plaintiffs William Scott Phillips and Suzanne Schmidt Phillips have filed a $5 million class-action lawsuit against Apple alleging that the Wi-Fi Assist feature on the iPhone resulted in data overcharges, Apple Insider reported .
In the complaint — filed in U.S. District Court in San Jose, Calif. — the Cupertino-based company is accused of negligent misrepresentation, and breaching California's Unfair Competition Law and False Advertising Law.
APPLE ADDS SUPPORT PAGE TO PROVE IOS 9 WI-FI ASSIST IS NOT EATING UP USERS' DATA
A screenshot of the Wi-fi Assist enabled on the iPhone. The new feature on iOS 9 is enabled by default after installing Apple's operating system on iPhone 5 models or later.
Wi-Fi Assist automatically switches your device to cellular data usage when there is a weak wireless connection.
When the feature is turned on, users may "use more cellular data," but that "this should only be a small percentage higher than previous usage," according to Apple's website .
For the Phillips, that update on the company website was not good enough.
"Defendant's above corrective action, however, still downplays the possible data overcharges a user could incur," the suit argues.
"Reasonable and average consumers use their iPhones for streaming of music, videos, and running various applications — all of which can use significant data. Defendant's corrective statement does not disclose any basis for its conclusion that an average consumer would not see much increase in cellular usage."
